text: (gentle upbeat music)
I would like to talk to you today
about some of the Main-Group work
that we're doing in my group at the University of Virginia.
But before I get started, I would, of course like
to thank Chemical and Engineering News
for this amazing honor.
I would also like to congratulate the other awardees.
But I noticed in the issue,
there was this part on undiscovered reactivity.
And I kinda wanna build on that for my talk,
that kind of demonstrate how really fundamental advances
can lead to really interesting applications.
So in my group, we study Main-Group chemistry,
mostly focused on unusual elements in the S and P block.
It's not that we don't do any transition metal,
but the core of our program is certainly
in Main-Group chemistry.
And Main-Group has been the subject of recent
special issues in inorganic chemistry and organic metallics
and stay tuned for the special issue
this year in Organometallics,
that I had the pleasure of guest editing on the,
it's an update on the Organometallic chemistry
of the Main-Group Elements.
So in terms of the work that we do in my group,
you've already heard a lot of information
about the catalysis and developing redox cycles,
low valence, low coordinate molecules.
And we do all of that as it relates to
Subvalent and Cationic Pnictinidenes.
So those are group 15 compounds.
We've also done quite a bit of work in that area,
as it relates to the alkaline earth metals.
More recently, we've been studying carbon dioxide reduction
as it relates to using these carbene ligands as mediators.
But I kinda want to talk about something different today
because many people know that we're working
on that type of chemistry.
Most folks don't know that we're doing
Main-Group materials type work for energy conversion.
So I like to give a little bit of detail
on that type of work that we've been working on.
So we've been trying to make Thermochromic Materials.
And those are materials that change color
due to a change in temperature.
Many people will be familiar with different types of paints
for cars and things of that nature.
You'll see cars that change color based on the weather.
There are some of those type cars.
There're more playful items like spoons for kids.
There're baby bottles, that change color,
for example, when it's okay for the kid
to consume the liquid substance.
There're thermochromic mugs.
There have also been discussions
about thermochromic materials and dyes
being useful for uniforms for soldiers.
So instead of having to carry around a uniform
that has multiple uniforms, various colors,
you can have one uniform that adapts
to the different terrains.
For example, the desert versus being in a jungle.
So those are the types of applications
of thermochromic materials that we're interested in.
To tell you a little bit about the types
of compounds we make,
I need to mention a little bit about
the chemistry behind it.
So we've been making Organoboron cations in my lab.
So based on the coordination number of the boron center,
we give them different names.
And we've been mostly interested in Borenium type cations.
So about 15 years ago, there was a review by Warren Piers.
And there's a quote from that review, but I'll read,
"Boron cations are elusive and highly electrophilic species
that play a key role in the chemistry of boron.
Despite early interest in the chemistry of boron cations,
until recently they have largely remained
chemical curiosities."
So at that time, people were really just happy
to isolate these molecules.
They were interested in them for their fundamental chemistry
and some people thought that they were so electrophilic
that they could not be isolated.
So I'll show you how far we've come
in a relatively short period of time.
Now that these, we know that these compounds
are very useful for catalysis
and I'll demonstrate the types of
materials relevant projects that we're working on.
So skipping some of the synthetic methods we can
make boron cations that are encapsulated in a hetero cycle.
So my group does a lot of x-ray crystallography
to look at the bonding and detail
for these types of molecules.
So we can make five member rings.
We have also been able to make
the seven member ring analogs
and these have various electronic properties,
but I'll demonstrate the application
that I think is very useful
for these molecules at this point.
So if you look at the structure
on the left-hand side of the screen,
you'll see a tri-coordinate boron center
that is cationic.
That particular compound is red at room temperature,
but when you start to cool it,
it will change color to colorless, the same molecule.
And that's because you have this
intermolecular oxygen boron interaction going on.
And that process is completely reversible, okay.
If you do the same reaction in a different solvent,
you see a bit of Solvatochromism going on
and you can go from orange to colors.
And again, that process is reversible.
And to my knowledge, this is the first
thermochromic borenium ion.
So that is quite a significant advance, in my opinion.
Going from compounds that one thought you couldn't isolate.
We've been able to develop a range
of these types of compounds now.
We can make borepins, borafluorenes.
We can make radical species.
So radicals are interesting for materials chemists
for charge transport and storage applications.
We can even dope these molecules with other hetero atoms.
So not just boron.
We can make boron phosphorous type materials,
and that is demonstrated in the bottom right-hand side
of the screen.
So we're making a range of these compounds now
that really originated from just
the fundamental interest for real applications.
And that is demonstrated in the next slide
from what I think is the next big thing for our group.
And these results will come out over the next year or so.
We've been able to now make
thermoluminescent borenium ions,
and we're working on their optical electronic
and device applications.
So you can see on the screen is one borenium ion.
On the left hand side of the screen,
you'll see that at different temperatures,
they are different fluorescent properties.
Also in the solid state, it looks very different.
So you can see the blue fluorescent compound
in the second picture
and these give high quantum yields up to 80% or so.
And also, depending on how we drop-cast these compounds
and make thin films,
they also show different properties.
And that's because this is really dependent
on the molecular packing of these materials.
So this is something that we were working on
right before we had to shut down
because of the Corona virus.
And we're now working on incorporating these into devices
of colleagues in Chemical Engineering at UVA,
the Geary and Choi groups.
So this is one of the areas that I think,
you know, this chemistry will have a huge impact
in the development of OLAP type technology moving forward.
We're also in my group working on
Boron-Doped PI-Electron type materials.
So these are conjugated systems,
which we linked by molecules like pyrene.
And then we laid two boracyclic fragments,
depending on the structural properties,
the twisting of these molecules in solution
can also get different properties.
And we've been able to extend this,
not only to pyrene-based systems,
but also to benzene fused analogs.
But you can see the beautiful luminescent properties
that we can elicit from these molecules.
And we're now being able to develop,
you know, tunability among these systems as well.
So what's next for Main-Group chemistry in general?
Main-Group chemists have always been able
to develop interesting structures, unusual molecules,
push the boundaries of bonding concepts.
But I really think moving forward,
it's gonna be our goal to really understand
the impact of a chemical structure
on the function of these molecules.
This is gonna impact Chemical Synthesis,
Redox active Main-Group molecules,
Catalyst Design, Optical Properties.
And I think moving forward,
it's gonna have a huge impact on the development
of new electronics.
Before I end, I have to thank collaborators
that have really advanced this science, advanced our program
and made me a better scientists.
I won't name folks,
but they're fairly really a large team
that has pushed this chemistry forward.
I like to thank probably the most important people
in terms of getting the work done.
And my research group has really been fantastic.
It has been a pleasure working with them
over the last two and a half to three years.
This chemistry, I didn't talk much about it,
but the synthetic work is extremely difficult
and it takes talented hands to do that.
These folks have really worked hard.
I'd also like to thank some key mentors
that have really supported me over the years,
especially in the last several years,
Rhett Smith, John Prontasiewics and Hansjorg Grutzmacher
also made contributions to the talented 12 issues.
So I really thank them for their guidance.
I'm really taking my experiences
from my undergraduate, graduate, postdoc work
and mashed it into some really new chemistry.
So I'm really excited about moving forward.
I'll be happy to answer your questions
and I thank you for your attention.
Thank you so much, Robert.
Those borenium materials are so beautiful.
I wonder, are there, you know,
and you've presented a lot of different colors.
Are there any colors that are like challenging to make
or that you can't make?
Yeah, so the more red shifted materials
are definitely more challenging to make
than the blue materials.
But this is something that we're working on
trying to incorporate a bit of design capability
'cause on the front end is kind of difficult for us
at this time to predict what colors
we're gonna get for these types of borenium ions.
And that's just because there are so few
that give these properties so far.
So that's definitely what we're gonna be
looking into moving forward.
And you mentioned you have a collaboration
with the chemical Engineering Department there at UVA?
Right.
I mean, can you talk at all about those applications
or are they top secret?
Yeah so, some of the compounds,
the borenium ions that you saw are being incorporated
into LEDs at this point.
So we're working on that with the Choi and Geary groups
in UV chemical engineering.
And yeah, that's about all I can say about that so far,
but we're working on that.
That just started right before we were shut down
due to the virus.
And in the chat someone asks if the borenium compounds
are water or product solvent sensitive?
Yeah so, both, so some of them are sensitive,
but the really advance that I think
I'm really excited about reporting very soon
is that we've started to make air stable ones.
And I think that's really important for future applications.
That was the next question.
Someone asked if they were, how air sensitive they were.
Yeah, the more recent ones are,
we have not reported results on that yet.
But we will be.
So when you see the colors,
is it just a total surprise
or is there any predictive nature in that?
You know, structural changes we made
that are similar to other compounds,
of course we can predict those,
but just because there's so little literature
on the types of borenium ions
that emit these types of colors,
it is kind of surprise until we can get the structure.
Well, that must be sort of delightful in your lab.
Yeah.
Do your students come to you and say,
"Look what I made, it's lovely."
Yes, and it doesn't even take them,
any time I see any colors,
they know that chemical structure
or some beautiful colors is one way
to get me out of the office and in the lab
to see what's going on.
So that is a nice aspect.

All right. Well thank you
Thank You
for a wonderful talk. I really appreciate it.
(gentle upbeat music)
